definition[0]: to officially state that something has no legal force
example[0]: The election results were nullified because of voter fraud.
definition[1]: to make something lose its effect or value
example[1]: Recent inflation could nullify the economic growth of the last several years.
definition[2]: to state officially that something does not have any legal force and is therefore considered not to exist
example[2]: The Illinois Supreme Court reversed the decision of two lower courts and nullified the publisherâ€™s contract.
example[3]: The surtax nullifies the benefit these taxpayers get from the lower, 15% tax rate.
